entry.title: Re: initial project stock upload 561Q is not reflected in...
entry.content:
You're absolutely right—this is a normal requirement in capital-intensive projects, engineering, construction, and defense sectors. Many organizations want visibility of:

  • Materials purchased or uploaded for a project
  • Stock sitting in inventory but earmarked for project use
  • Total committed value—even before consumption

To answer your question 'How others handle this', (to my knowledge), below are the most common approaches used across industries:

1. Use Commitment Tracking (Purchase Orders)

  • PO commitments are visible in project reports.
  • But once stock is received via 561Q, the commitment is cleared—and visibility is lost.

2. Custom Report Linking Inventory to WBS

Develop a report that shows:

  • Project stock quantity and value (from MMBE or MBBS)
  • Linked WBS element

This gives visibility without affecting cost reports.

3. Statistical Cost Posting

  • Post a manual statistical actual cost to the WBS using KB11N.
  • Use a statistical cost element so it doesn’t consume budget or distort actuals.
  • Document clearly that it represents unconsumed inventory.

4. Use Project Stock Valuation Reports

  • Reports like MBBS or S_ALR_87013558 can be customized to show stock value by WBS.
  • Not part of standard cost line items, but useful for project managers.

5. Enhanced Budgeting Logic

Some organizations extend budgeting logic to include inventory value as part of budget tracking. This requires custom development or integration with FM (Funds Management).

entry.title: Re: SXMSIF Configuration
entry.content:
Hi @naseemallika14 

Regarding your question on configuring. Let me walk you through it.

The Agency usually refers to the provider or authority responsible for the message or document exchange. It often represents a standardized body or organization defining the message formats or business rules.

The Schema defines the structure or format of the message or document. It corresponds to the XML schema or message type that governs how data elements are organized and validated in the integration.

The Party helps you identify the business partners involved in the message exchange, such as sender and receiver parties or systems. Each party represents a distinct entity or system participating in the communication scenario.

The Component typically means the technical component or system component responsible for sending or receiving the message. It helps direct and process the communication by mapping the interface to specific software components.

The SXMSIF fields help define the routing and processing of inbound and outbound messages by specifying who is sending or receiving which refers to the Party, under what Schema format, and which component or agency is involved.

I hope this provides the necessary information. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: initial project stock upload 561Q is not reflected in...
entry.content:
In order to make already uploaded project stock (via 561Q) visible in project cost reports—ideally without custom development, you can consider the below options:

Option 1: Controlled 221Q → 222Q with Statistical Cost Element

This is a refined version of the workaround you mentioned earlier, and while it’s not ideal, it can be used strategically:

How it works is you post 221Q to issue material to the WBS element. This creates a cost posting and consumes budget. Immediately post 222Q to return the material to project stock. This reverses the quantity movement, but the cost posting remains visible in the project line item report. Importantly, use a statistical cost element for the 221Q posting. This ensures it doesn’t consume budget or distort actual costs and the cost appears in the report, but is flagged as statistical.

Pros:
No custom report needed
Visible in standard project cost reports (CJI3, etc.)

Cons:
Requires careful configuration of cost elements
May confuse users if not documented properly

Option 2: Manual Actual Cost Posting via KB11N

If material movement isn’t feasible or desirable, you can post a manual actual cost to the WBS using KB11N. Use a statistical cost element. Reference the material document number or stock value in the text

Pros:
Clean and auditable
No physical stock movement

Cons:
Manual effort
Doesn’t reflect in inventory reports

Option 3: Reversal and Reposting with Correct Movement Type

If you're early in the project and stock hasn’t been consumed, reverse the 561Q using 562Q. Repost using a movement type that allows cost posting (e.g., 201Q or 221Q). Assign the correct WBS element and cost element

Pros:
Clean reposting with proper accounting
Reflects in both inventory and cost reports

Cons:
Operational risk if stock has already been partially consumed
May require coordination with MM and Finance teams

My recommendations would be if you want visibility without disrupting inventory, the 221Q → 222Q with statistical cost element is your best bet. It’s a controlled workaround that gives you reporting visibility while keeping the stock intact.

entry.title: SAP BTP Hackathon at SAPHILA 2025: Celebrating the Winners and Innovation in Action
entry.content:
From Ideation to Demo Jam: A Journey of Collaboration
As outlined in the previous blog, the hackathon was more than just a competition, it was a journey. Eighteen teams, representing a broad cross-section of AFSUG members, embarked on an eight-week sprint, supported by SAP BTP experts and coaches. The focus was on building real-world solutions using SAP BTP components like SAP Build, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Integration Suite and ABAP Cloud amongst other SAP BTP based Services & Solutions.

After intensive enablement and development sessions, three teams emerged as finalists and were invited to present their solutions live at SAPHILA 2025’s Demo Jam. The energy in the room was palpable as each team showcased how SAP BTP could be harnessed to solve pressing business challenges.

 

And the Winner Is… PwC South Africa!

In a closely contested finale, the SAPHILA audience voted PwC South Africa as the overall winner for their AI-driven legal services platform “Legal Ease”. This solution stood out for its innovative use of AI to simplify legal document processing and understanding, a pain point for many businesses and consumers alike. “Legal Ease” enables users to scan and summarize complex contracts, ask questions in natural language, and receive clear, actionable insights. The platform even supports translation into local languages and integrates with knowledge bases for related services.

What impressed both the jury and the audience was not just the technical sophistication, but the clear business value: “Legal Ease” addresses real frustrations around contract transparency, billing and accessibility, with the potential to transform how legal services are delivered in Africa and beyond.

 

Honouring the Finalists: Debswana Diamond Company and Bell Equipment

Let’s not forget the other two finalists, who also delivered outstanding solutions:

  • Debswana Diamond Company tackled overtime management with an AI-powered assistant that streamlines scheduling, reduces costs and supports employee well-being.
  • Bell Equipment automated shipment tracking and document processing, helping to prevent stock shortages and improve logistics efficiency.

Both teams demonstrated the breadth of innovation possible with SAP BTP and set a high bar for future Hackathons.

 

Reflections and What’s Next

The Hackathon’s main objective was to foster deep collaboration between SAP and its customers, giving local teams a hands-on opportunity to explore and build with SAP BTP. The quality and diversity of solutions, especially the creative use of AI and automation, highlight the immense potential within the African SAP community.

Amanda Gibbs, CEO of AFSUG, summed it up perfectly:

“It is inspiring to witness what can be achieved in just eight weeks using SAP BTP;

we’ve seen incredible progress and innovation.”

 

Join the Conversation

Congratulations again to all teams who participated and especially to PwC South Africa for their winning solution! If you were inspired by the SAP BTP Hackathon or have thoughts on how SAP BTP can drive innovation in your organization, I’d love to hear from you in the comments.

 

And if you missed out this year, keep an eye out for future SAP BTP Hackathons - this is just the beginning!

entry.title: Default Unit Pattern in sap/ui/core/format/NumberFormat now includes a non-breaking space
entry.content:
Intro

With a recent change in UI5 version 1.140, we have decided to include a non-breaking space in the default unit pattern. This way, the number and measure are guaranteed to stay in the same line, even with very small window sizes.

 

What's different?

If a value is formatted with sap/ui/core/format/NumberFormat.format and this function uses the default unit pattern (the fallback pattern if no other pattern is to be used) the resulting string will now include a non-breaking space between the number part and the measure part instead of a regular space. Using a respective type from sap/ui/model/type or sap/ui/model/odata/type to format values will also result in a string with a non-breaking space.

Example - Prior to the change:

  • Values to be formatted: ["50", "%"]
  • Formatted result: "50\u0020%"; \u0020 is a regular space character

Example - After to the change:

  • Values to be formatted: ["50", "%"]
  • Formatted result: "50\u00a0%"; \u00a0 is a non-breaking space character

                             

What does that mean for applications and tests?

Applications will only see a difference in the UI if the window size is small enough.
However tests might fail, as "50\u0020%" is not strict equal to "50\u00a0%": you need to adjust your test in this case.

entry.title: Re: Why Clean Core matters - Get some insights into the about our brand new Extensibility Whitepaper
entry.content:
Hello,

regarding my question "rating of InApp-/KeyUser-Tools" -> this is answered. (Thank you Daniel!)

I got the hint to check the FAQ of the Whitepaper -> "QC1: How does the level concept translate to the ABAP language versions (ABAP Cloud for developers, ABAP Cloud for key users)?"

All customer objects with language version “ABAP Cloud for Developers” (language version 5) and “ABAP Cloud for Key Users” (language version 2) are considered level A. This guarantees that these objects are only referencing released SAP objects.
In addition, there are objects in customer namespace which are generated when developing with ABAP Cloud for Key Users, which technically have ABAP classic language version, but which are still considered level A. With the correction from SAP note 3593439 these are also correctly detected.
All customer objects in levels B, C or D have language version ABAP classic.

Thank you and have a great day.

Regards, Thomas F!

entry.title: SAP Databricks: How to use AutoML to forecast sales data - Part 3
entry.content:
Part 1 – SQL analytics with SAP Data Products
Part 2 – Build and deploy Mosaic AI and Agent Tools
Part 3 – How to use AutoML to forecast sales data
Part 4 – End-to-end integration: SAP Databricks, SAP Datasphere, and SAP Analytics Cloud
Part 5 – Create inferences and endpoints for application integration with SAP Build

 

SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud

With SAP Databricks you have access to an amazing set of capabilities to work with your BDC Data Products and other data.

 

 

Let’s look at just one feature of SAP Databricks – how we can use the AutoML Forecasting feature to predict time-series data.

 

How to use AutoML to forecast sales data

How can we analyse a dataset and make forecasts without having deep understanding of machine learning?

One way is to use AutoML which will automatically create the code and run machine learning experiments behind the scenes and then provide you with the best result at the end.

SAP Databricks has a feature to build AutoML models for you – you just point it at the data and let it rip!

 

Data

For this exercise we are going to look at sales data and see if we can create an accurate forecast.

The S/4HANA system that I have available in my BDC formation has a sales_order data product available, however, after a quick investigation it's a very limited and small dataset with large multi-month gaps in the data, which is not a realistic dataset for forecasting.

For the purposes of this blog post, let's create some realistic sample data instead.

So even with AutoML - there is no excuse but to learn about your data!

 

We will create sample data and save it as a delta table: workspace.default.demo_product_sales_forecast.

 

Note:
The SAP Databricks catalog (or Unity Catalog you will see it called) structures artefacts in a format like:
- Catalog (defaulted to the name workspace but you can create many catalogs)
            - Schema (your initial schema will be called default)
                        - Table, Model, etc

 

The dataset includes several different products, and the amount sold each month over a multi-year period to consider any seasonality effects.

We will look to train a forecast model using SAP Databricks' built-in Serverless AutoML Forecast capability.

 

Note: SQL function ai_forecast()
You can also perform forecasting with a prophet based model using the SQL function ai_forecast. It only works on the serverless SQL compute however, so you cannot execute it from a Notebook which runs on the all-purpose serverless compute.
Check the ai_forecast() documentation for details and limitations.
Depending on the complexity of your data, this AutoML technique can provide better results and offers more tuning options.

 

Sample dataset

In your SAP Databricks workspace click the “Create” button and create a new python notebook.

Add a new python cell containing the following to install some modules we will use later:

%pip install databricks-automl-runtime prophet
%restart_python

And now the cell for sample data creation:

# Build a sales data set for forecasting

import pandas as pd, numpy as np
from itertools import product
from pyspark.sql import SparkSession

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# 1. CONFIG – tweak to taste
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
skus       = ["SKU_A", "SKU_B", "SKU_C", "SKU_D"]
price_map  = {"SKU_A": 25.0, "SKU_B": 40.0, "SKU_C": 33.0, "SKU_D": 18.0}
start, end = "2019-01-01", "2025-12-01"            # 7 full years, monthly freq
rng        = np.random.default_rng(42)             # reproducible

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# 2. SYNTHETIC DATA FABRICATION
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
dates = pd.date_range(start, end, freq="MS")        # Month-Start stamps
# WEEKLY
# dates = pd.date_range("2019-01-07", "2025-12-29", freq="W-MON")
# or DAILY
# dates = pd.date_range("2019-01-01", "2025-12-31", freq="D")
rows  = []
for sku, ts in product(skus, dates):
    #   volume dynamics ------------------------------------------------------
    base   = {"SKU_A":380, "SKU_B":240, "SKU_C":310, "SKU_D":700}[sku]
    trend  = {"SKU_A":  6, "SKU_B":  9, "SKU_C":  4, "SKU_D": -3}[sku] * (ts.year-2019)
    seas   = 80 * np.sin(2*np.pi*ts.month/12 + {"SKU_A":0, "SKU_B":1,
                                                "SKU_C":2, "SKU_D":3}[sku])
    promo  = 120 if ts.month in (11, 12) else 0     # holiday lift
    noise  = rng.normal(0, 40)
    units  = max(0, int(base + trend + seas + promo + noise))
    
    #   revenue = units × price ± small discount noise -----------------------
    net_amt = round(units * price_map[sku] * rng.uniform(0.97, 1.03), 2)
    
    rows.append((sku, ts, units, net_amt))

df = pd.DataFrame(rows, columns=["SKU",              #   ← series identifier
                                 "SalesOrderDate",   #   ← time column
                                 "UnitsSold",        #   ← target 1
                                 "TotalNetAmount"])  #   ← target 2 (optional)

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
# 3. LAND AS A DELTA TABLE
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
(spark.createDataFrame(df)
      .write.format("delta").mode("overwrite")
      .saveAsTable("demo_product_sales_forecast"))

# Quick visual sanity-check (optional)
display(spark.table("demo_product_sales_forecast")
              .orderBy("SalesOrderDate", "SKU")
              .limit(12))

Execute these cells and you will now have a new table in the catalog called demo_product_sales_forecast.

 

AutoML Forecast – configure and train

Now we have our sample data generated by our python notebook, let’s use SAP Databricks inbuilt function to create a machine learning model using AutoML.

 

Steps within the SAP Databricks cockpit:

  1. Navigate to AI/ML -> Experiments in the left menu bar and click the forecasting (preview) box


     



  2. Populate the required fields.
    Enter workspace.default.demo_product_sales_forecast as the training data (this is the sample data table we previously created with a python notebook)

  3. Choose SalesOrderDate as the Time Column

  4. Choose UnitsSold (or TotalNetAmount) for the Target Column (the value we want to be able to predict)

  5. Choose Monthly for Forecast Frequency

  6. Set 12 months for the Forecast Horizon

  7. Enter workspace.default as the prediction path (or any other Unity Catalog path of your choosing) and demo_product_sales_forecast_predictions as the prediction table

  8. Enter the location where you want the model saved and its name (e.g. workspace.default and sales_forecast)

  9. Under Advanced Options, choose column SKU as the time-series identifier (IMPORTANT! Since this dataset covers multiple different products)

 

Finally, click Start Training.

 

With this sample dataset, training can take around 20mins.
AutoML is pre-processing the data, tuning a forecasting model
by building many different types of models with different 
hyperparameters and finally training (fit) on the data using 
the best model and parameters.

 

See it creating experiments as it tunes the model now:

 

SAP Databricks uses the MLFlow frameworks for MLOps, which enables history to be captured and for you to create reproducible workflows.

 

Training results

At the end of the training run the best model is chosen based on a hyperparameter search and saved (and registered) to the unity catalog in SAP Databricks.

 

A table of predictions is created as a result (you provided the name when configuring AutoML). The best trained model is also saved and registered into the unity catalog (with the name you entered e.g. sales_forecast).

 

View the forecast result

You can switch back to your python notebook (or open the SAP Databricks SQL editor) to view the data with:

%sql
select * from demo_product_sales_foreacast_predictions

 

Visual sanity check.

We can use the following code cell in your notebook to plot the historical (training) data and extend it with the 12-month forecast.

import pandas as pd, matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# ── grab data ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
hist_tbl = "demo_product_sales_forecast"
pred_tbl = "demo_product_sales_foreacast_predictions"   # name from AutoML wizard

hist = spark.table(hist_tbl).toPandas()
pred = spark.table(pred_tbl).toPandas()

# ensure date columns are pandas Timestamps
hist["SalesOrderDate"] = pd.to_datetime(hist["SalesOrderDate"])
pred["SalesOrderDate"] = pd.to_datetime(pred["SalesOrderDate"])

# ── plot per SKU ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
for sku in hist["SKU"].unique():
    h = hist[hist["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")
    p = pred[pred["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")
    
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 4))
    
    ax.plot(h["SalesOrderDate"], h["UnitsSold"], label="actual", linewidth=2)
    ax.plot(p["SalesOrderDate"], p["predicted_UnitsSold"],
            label="forecast", linestyle="--")
    
    ax.fill_between(
        p["SalesOrderDate"],
        p["predicted_UnitsSold_lower"],
        p["predicted_UnitsSold_upper"],
        alpha=0.25,
        label="95 % Confidence"
    )
    
    ax.set_title(f"Units Sold – {sku}")
    ax.set_xlabel("Date")
    ax.set_ylabel("Units")
    ax.legend()
    ax.grid(True)
    
    plt.show()

 

Output for one of the products:

 

We can see it looks pretty good and has captured the cyclical nature of the sales data well.

 

Let’s now back-test the forecast to see how good it works and compare it to the last 12 months of training data. We can do this by cutting off the training data 12 months early and forecasting for that cut-off 12 months.

Note: what we are doing here is actually leaking training data into our test which is bad practice in a real life scenario but it's just a quick way to visualise how the forecast works. In real life we should carve out some of our training data (e.g. the last months or year maybe) and perform the below test on that data.

Use this cell to plot actual vs. prediction.

# 📊 Back-test: forecast last 12 months per SKU and plot
import mlflow, pandas as pd, numpy as np, matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# ── 1. LOAD THE REGISTERED MODEL ──────────────────────────────────────────
uc_model_path     = "workspace.default.sales_forecast"     # fully-qualified UC model
model_version_uri = f"models:/{uc_model_path}@most_recent"

mlflow.set_registry_uri("databricks-uc")                  # point MLflow at UC
model = mlflow.pyfunc.load_model(model_version_uri)       # pulls pipeline incl. featurizer

# ── 2. HISTORICAL DATA ────────────────────────────────────────────────────
hist = (spark.table("demo_product_sales_forecast")
           .toPandas()
           .sort_values(["SKU", "SalesOrderDate"]))
hist["SalesOrderDate"] = pd.to_datetime(hist["SalesOrderDate"])

# ── 3. HOLD-OUT = last 12 rows per SKU ────────────────────────────────────
holdout_idx = hist.groupby("SKU").tail(12).index
score_df    = hist.loc[holdout_idx].copy().reset_index(drop=True)
train_df    = hist.drop(index=holdout_idx)

# ── 4. PREDICT ON HOLD-OUT ────────────────────────────────────────────────
features = score_df.drop(columns=["UnitsSold"])           # only drop the target
yhat     = model.predict(features).reset_index(drop=True) # returns a Series named 'yhat'
score_df["predicted_UnitsSold"] = yhat                    # attach forecast column

# (optional) prediction intervals if the pipeline supports them:
# try:
#     pi = model.predict_interval(features, coverage=0.95).reset_index(drop=True)
#     score_df = pd.concat([score_df, pi], axis=1)
# except AttributeError:
#     pass

# ── 5. SMAPE helper ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────
def smape(actual, forecast):
    denom = np.abs(actual) + np.abs(forecast)
    return np.mean(np.where(denom == 0, 0, 200 * np.abs(actual - forecast) / denom))

# ── 6. PLOT PER SKU ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────
for sku in hist["SKU"].unique():
    h = hist[hist["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")
    p = score_df[score_df["SKU"] == sku].sort_values("SalesOrderDate")

    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 4))
    ax.plot(h["SalesOrderDate"], h["UnitsSold"],
            label="actual", lw=2)
    ax.plot(p["SalesOrderDate"], p["predicted_UnitsSold"],
            label="back-test forecast", lw=2, ls="--", color="orange")

    # uncomment if interval columns exist
    # if {"predicted_UnitsSold_lower", "predicted_UnitsSold_upper"}.issubset(p.columns):
    #     ax.fill_between(p["SalesOrderDate"],
    #                     p["predicted_UnitsSold_lower"],
    #                     p["predicted_UnitsSold_upper"],
    #                     color="orange", alpha=0.15, label="95 % PI")

    sku_smape = smape(p["UnitsSold"], p["predicted_UnitsSold"])
    #ax.set_title(f"{sku} – Back-test SMAPE: {sku_smape:.2%}")
    ax.set_title(f"{sku} – Back-test SMAPE: {sku_smape/100:.2%}")
    ax.set_xlabel("Date"); ax.set_ylabel("Units")
    ax.legend(); ax.grid(True)
    plt.show()

 

 

Conclusion

Forecasting time-series data with SAP Databricks is made far easier thanks to AutoML which takes away the work of cleaning your data (pre-processing step); hyperparameter tuning by building many model experiments and capturing them in MLFow (tuning step) and finally training the best model architecture to suit your data (training step).

You might also be wondering – why – why bother with this and instead use an LLM to do it all? Well, the answer is that LLM’s just aren’t that good at working with tabular data. For very small datasets – absolutely – throw it into ChatGPT for some analysis. But for real scenarios we still rely on classic machine learning approaches as shown here…

entry.title: Future of Feature Toggles
entry.content:
Dear all, 

I am currently member in a migration project to S4 Hana.
We currently use a self-developed framework that also has a "feature toggle" functionality.

When I looked into the topic of feature toggles a few years ago, I discovered that SAP has an own implementation of feature toggles in S4.

Now I wanted to test this and the result is:

  • Legacy feature toggles are marked as deprecated in Eclipse.
  • Switch-Based Feature Toggles cannot be created on customer systems.

What is the future here in on premise / private cloud?

The idea of a feature toggle is a temporary switch. As soon as the feature has been fully developed and rolled out to all users, it should be removed.
Therefore, in my opinion, there is nothing to be said against the usage of "legacy feature toggles", as they are meant only to be used temporarily in the code.

In case the framework is deleted by SAP, the legacy feature toggles should have been removed and deleted again following the idea of clean code.

At least I do not find "cl_feature_toggle"  in the current simplification database :-).

What's your opinion?
Is there a better alternative?

Regards
Jürgen

entry.title: Re: Restricting BNK_MONI T-code
entry.content:
BNK_MONI is a monitoring transaction, not a posting or execution transaction. It’s primarily used to view payment statuses and batches.

SAP designed it to check F_STAT_MON, which includes fields like:

  • Authorization group
  • Payment medium status
  • Payment run status

It does not include company code as a restriction field, which means you can't directly restrict access by company code using standard authorization objects.

Here are some approaches and Best Practices which you can also try

1. Authorization Groups
Assign different authorization groups to payment batches based on company code. Then restrict F_STAT_MON by authorization group. This requires customizing your payment configuration to tag batches appropriately.

2. Custom Enhancement (BAdI or User Exit)
Implement a custom check via enhancement in BNK_MONI or related function modules. You can intercept the selection logic and restrict based on user’s company code authorization.

3. Role-Based UI Restriction
If you're using SAP Fiori apps, you can apply restriction types at the business catalog level. For example, restrict by company code using the “Company Code” restriction field in the role definition.

entry.title: Re: SAP CIS Identity Provisioning Service integration with SAP HANA Cloud, HANA Database
entry.content:
Dear @pavlomelnyk ,

Thank you for your excellent blog post on setting up the provisioning framework to SAP HANA Cloud DB via IPS. Following your guidance, we successfully implemented the scenario.

We now have a new requirement to assign an additional Identity Provider (SAML) to the user record for an SAC Live Data connection. Our goal is to achieve this through IPS provisioning by setting the SAC SAML IdP in addition to the existing JWT provider.

However, it appears that the SCIM schema supports only one IdP entry per user. When we attempted to provision an additional SAML IdP via IPS, it overwrote the existing JWT provider in the user record. We confirmed that it is possible to maintain an additional IdP manually via the UI, which we did for testing purposes.

To verify this, we performed a GET request via Postman to check the SCIM schema for the user. Unfortunately, the additional IdP did not appear in the schema, leading us to conclude that only one IdP can be provisioned via IPS.

We have also opened a ticket with SAP Support. While they are currently investigating, they advised us to post this question in the SAP Community as well. We believe this may be a broader use case, as there are scenarios where users would need both IdPs:

  • JWT for SSO access at the DB level

  • SAML IdP for consuming data via SAC Live Data connection

Do you have any experience or insights regarding this requirement?

Thank you in advance for your feedback.

Kind regards,

Alex

entry.title: Re: Determining Directory Path of Solution Management Doc...
entry.content:
Hello
In Solman 7.2 system documents are stored by default in table SMDCONT. Every Document has a unique LOIO ID - this is stored in table SMDLOIO. Every changes to a document created a new version and a new PHIO ID - those are stored in table SMDPHIO.
The file size of a document can be seen in table SMDPHF - by providing the PHIOID. 

Generally to reduce table size of SMDCONT - you may refer to Note
https://me.sap.com/notes/0003317599
2956173 - Delete orphan documents in Solution Documentation with SOLMAN_UNUSED_72_DOCUMENTS

Best Regards
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Batch Derivation and Co-Product
entry.content:
Why it is not working is because, SAP’s standard batch derivation setup assumes:

  • One receiver batch (typically the header material).
  • Multiple sender batches (components).

This is known as pull derivation, and it’s designed to derive characteristics from components to the main product. Co-products, however, are treated differently in the process order structure and may not be included in the default derivation event unless explicitly configured.

You can try the below methods

Use Push Derivation
Push derivation allows one sender to multiple receivers, which is ideal for co-products. You must configure condition records for push derivation using transaction DVC1 or DVCO. Set the derivation event to trigger during confirmation or goods receipt.

Maintain Condition Records for Co-Product

In transaction DVCO, create a condition record where:

  • Sender = Component C1
  • Receiver = Co-product SF1
  • Assign characteristic C1

Ensure the derivation rule is set to static or dynamic based on your needs.

Activate Derivation Event for Co-Product
Go to SPRO → Logistics - General → Batch Management → Derivation of Batch Data → Define Derivation Events. Ensure the event (e.g., goods receipt or confirmation) is active for co-product derivation.

Check Batch Where-Used List Activation
Batch derivation relies on the Batch Where-Used List (BaWU). Make sure synchronous posting is enabled so the system tracks sender-receiver relationships correctly.

entry.title: SAP EHS Environment Management - environmental responsibility and regulatory compliance
entry.content:
To assure environmental responsibility, regulatory compliance, and sustainable operations, SAP offers a comprehensive suite of solutions within SAP Environment, Health, and Safety – Environment Management, tailored to the needs of environmental managers, compliance specialists, and sustainability leaders.

At the heart of these solutions is the ability to centrally manage, monitor, and report on environmental aspects across the enterprise – from air emissions to regulatory obligations and waste streams – ensuring alignment with both legal requirements and corporate sustainability strategies.

Emission Management enables organizations to track, calculate, and report air pollutant and greenhouse gas emissions in line with local and international standards. By integrating operational data, it facilitates accurate emissions inventories, regulatory submissions, and transparent reporting, supporting both environmental impact reduction and corporate climate objectives.

Compliance Management provides a structured approach to managing all environmental obligations – whether arising from legislation, permits, or internal policies. Through a central repository for requirements and integrated task tracking, the solution reduces compliance risks, ensures timely execution, and enables clear documentation to demonstrate regulatory adherence.

Waste Management covers the complete lifecycle of waste handling – from identification and classification to transport, treatment, and final disposal – ensuring compliance with environmental regulations and corporate sustainability commitments. It streamlines waste tracking, documentation for hazardous and non-hazardous materials, and reporting for regulatory or internal purposes.

Below, you will find an introductory video for each of these topics, offering a concise overview of the solution scope and a glimpse into the user experience through mini demos. These videos highlight how SAP EHS Environment Management empowers organizations to operate sustainably, maintain compliance, and enhance environmental performance.

entry.title: Re: Unable to settle WBS Element
entry.content:
The root cause and the error you're facing likely stems from how SAP treats cost element category 31:

These are secondary cost elements, used internally for allocations and RA calculations.
They do not post directly to FI, and are typically used in RA versions (configured via transaction OKG9) to calculate WIP or revenue recognition.

If you're seeing an error during WBS processing, it may be because:

The system is trying to settle or post using this technical cost element, which isn't allowed.
Or, the RA key or version is misconfigured, causing the system to misinterpret the cost element's role.

Below are the recommended approach

1. Review RA Version in OKG9
Confirm that the cost element is assigned correctly to a line ID in the RA version. Ensure the line ID is marked as technical and not intended for settlement or posting.

2. Check Posting Rules in OKG8
The actual posting to FI happens via OKG8, where you define which cost elements post to which GL accounts. Make sure the technical cost element is not included in posting rules unless explicitly required.

3. Validate Settlement Profile
Go to CJ2B or CJ20N and check the settlement profile on the WBS element. Ensure it allows settlement only for valid cost elements and not technical ones.

4. Run RA Simulation (KKA2)
Use KKA2 to simulate RA and see how the system is treating the cost element. This can help pinpoint if the error is due to incorrect cost element usage or missing configuration.

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud - Data Actions - Advance Formula...
entry.content:
Hi @PS_1978 

Although your requirement is not entirely clear, the example script you provided can be replaced with the single-formula script below, and the system will produce the same calculated result.

MEMBERSET [d/CostCenter] = ("CALC-REG", "CALC-MERIT")
MEMBERSET [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = ("GL_1", "GL_2")
MEMBERSET [d/Date] = PREVIOUS(2, "MONTH", %Date%) TO %Date%

DATA([d/DATASRC] = "CALC-REG", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "GL_SALARIED", [d/Date] = %Date%)
= RESULTLOOKUP()
* (RESULTLOOKUP([d/MEASURE_TYPE] = [d/HRPOSITION].[p/CORP_GRADE], [d/DATASRC] = "INPUT", [d/Measures] = "PERCENTAGE", [d/GL_ACCOUNT] = "#", [d/CURRENCY] = "#", [d/COSTCENTER] = "#", [d/HRPOSITION] = "#", [d/EMPLOYEE] = "#", [d/START_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/END_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/SHIFT] = "#", [d/TERM_DATE] = "2200-12-31", [d/GRADE] = "#", [d/EMPCATE] = "#", [d/EMPSTAT] = "#", [d/LABOR_TYPE] = "#"))

External Parameter %Date%

 

I hope this is helpful to you, and if I have misunderstood anything, please feel free to reach out.

Moonjun

entry.title: From Automation to Intelligence: How Joule Studio is Shaping the Future of SAP
entry.content:
The year 2025 has marked a significant turning point in enterprise technology, with AI agents becoming integral to operations across nearly every business line. SAP has been at the forefront of this transformation, introducing groundbreaking innovations such as Joule Studio, designed to empower organizations with intelligent automation and seamless workflow orchestration. 

Automations and workflows are streamlining repetitive manual tasks, while AI agents are increasingly being used to perform tasks autonomously across various business lines. And industry leaders are demanding automations and AI agents to make sure they remain in the competition and do not miss out on the advantages that these solutions bring to the table. Joule Studio provides abilities to SAP developers and users to build, deploy and run Custom Joule Skills and Custom Joule Agents in a short span of time.

Joule Studio brings in ease of use by abstracting all the technicalities and providing an interactive UI to build Custom Joule Skills and Custom Joule Agents in on-the-go fashion in SAP Build. One of the features of Joule Studio is that it enables the creation of Custom Joule Skills. Custom Joule Skills are nothing but automations of any manual, repetitive and rule-based task like reading data from a website and updating the same in SAP HANA cloud database. Read about the difference between Joule Skills and SAP BPA automations in this FAQ Blog.

Custom Joule Skills thus built get utilised by Custom Joule Agents created in Joule Studio. Building a Custom Joule Agent is even easier than assembling Lego blocks. Joule Studio acts as a helper and instructor right from the start of interaction asking specifications and providing options to choose from. Please note that Custom Joule Agent building feature is currently in beta and expected to be released in coming months.

 

Why Joule Studio?

Joule Studio provides one-stop-shop for building ‘Joule Skills’ and ‘Joule Agents’ with an exceptionally user-friendly interface. A developer or user can interact with Joule Studio in natural language and get all the assistance needed for building Custom Joules Skills or Custom Joule Agents.

Another advantage of choosing Joule Studio over other non-SAP AI tools is that ‘Joule Studio’ understands SAP and its mechanism is deeply grounded in the business processes and the data of the SAP systems. This provides significant advantage when developing cross-module automation. Thus, providing seamless user-experience across or non-uniform SAP landscape.

Although Joule comes with lots of pre-built Joule Skills in various LOBs like Finance, Procurement etc., Joule Studio can be used now to build Custom Joule Skills adding user specific features and outcomes. The existing processes and workflows can be reused while building the Joule Skills. Security setup in Joule is based on principal propagation. Existing BTP setup can be used to configure security in Joule. Additionally, Joule Studio has features of data masking and data filtering for security and compliance purposes.

 

Prerequisites to setup Joule Studio -

Setting up Joule Studio has broadly three prerequisites. First, you should be subscribed to Joule. Second, subscription to SAP Build using build-default service plan is required and you should have an SAP BTP sub account with SAP Build Process Automation. Third, you should subscribe to SAP Cloud Identity Services in SAP BTP. This SAP documentation provides clear steps to setup Joule Studio.

What else can be done to make sure that we get business value out of Joule Studio based solutions?

Both Custom Joule Skills and Custom Joule Agents are built with the help of building blocks like existing workflows, automations, grounding data, business data and processes. Here are some of the ways to make sure that these are more efficient, insightful, and aligned with strategic goals –

  • Pay attention to the data. It should be accurate to reflect the real-world values. It should be complete and without missing values. The data should be consistent across the landscape for better insight. And the data should be up-to-date and available when needed.
  • To make automations and workflows more effective make sure that high-impact use cases are prioritized. The automations should be intuitive and transparent meaning these should minimize clicks and decision points and should provide visibility of the status of the ongoing tasks. Further, these should be designed to integrate across systems and should have embedded intelligence to provide improved outcomes based on data.
  • It is important to regularly measure and optimize automations. Have governance in place and finally promote the adoption by offering training and support.

To conclude, I recommend reading Michael Ameling's blog on Joule Studio.

entry.title: Re: Implicit and Explicit enhancement
entry.content:
Below are some of the Real-World scenarios & practical differences

1. Upgrade Safety
Explicit: These are upgrade-safe because SAP acknowledges and maintains these points. During upgrades, your enhancements are preserved.
Implicit: While generally safe, they are less predictable during upgrades. If SAP changes the structure of the method or removes it, your enhancement might break.
Example:
In a custom sales order validation, using an explicit enhancement point in MV45AFZZ ensures your logic remains intact across ECC to S/4HANA migration. An implicit enhancement at the end of a method might be lost if the method is refactored.

2. Debugging & Traceability
Explicit: Easier to identify and debug. They appear clearly in the enhancement framework.
Implicit: Can be harder to trace, especially in large systems with multiple developers.
Example:
During a production issue, a developer can quickly locate an explicit enhancement in BADI_SD_SALES but might miss an implicit enhancement added at the end of a method in a custom class.

3. Governance & Documentation
Explicit: Often part of formal development processes. Easier to document and review.
Implicit: Sometimes used as quick fixes or temporary solutions, which may lack proper documentation.
Example:
In a regulated industry (e.g., pharma), explicit enhancements are preferred due to audit requirements. Implicit ones might raise compliance concerns.

4. Flexibility vs. Control
Explicit: Offers controlled flexibility. You can only enhance where SAP allows.
Implicit: Offers more flexibility, but with the risk of unintended side effects.
Example:
If you need to add a logging mechanism at the end of a standard method and no explicit enhancement exists, an implicit enhancement might be your only option—but it should be used cautiously.

Best Practices

  • Prefer explicit enhancements for long-term, stable customizations.
  • Use implicit enhancements only when no explicit options exist and document them thoroughly.
  • Always test enhancements during upgrades and regression cycles.

entry.title: CSV Download in RAP via SEGW
entry.content:
Introduction :

This blog walks you through the step-by-step approach to enable CSV downloads in a RAP application using SEGW, making data export simple and user‑friendly for end users.

Steps to Enable CSV Download in a RAP Application Using SEGW:

Step 1:  Create a Basic View – Define a basic CDS view based on the source table or view.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Basic View for SO - CSV File'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
@VDM.viewType: #BASIC
define view entity z6na_cds_bv_so_csv as select from I_SalesOrder
{
    key SalesOrder,
    key _Item.SalesOrderItem,
        _Item.Material,
        _Item._MaterialText.MaterialName,
        @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'OrderQuantityUnit'
        _Item.OrderQuantity,
        _Item.OrderQuantityUnit
}

Step 2:  Create a Root View Entity – Build a root view entity on top of the basic view and apply the required metadata extension annotation.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Root View Entity for SO- CSV'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity z6na_cds_rv_so_csv as select from z6na_cds_bv_so_csv
{
    key SalesOrder,
    key SalesOrderItem,
         Material,
         MaterialName,
         @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'OrderQuantityUnit'
         OrderQuantity,
         OrderQuantityUnit
}

 Step 3: Define a Metadata Extension and apply the required UI annotations.

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
annotate entity z6na_cds_rv_so_csv
  with  
{
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10,label: 'SalesOrder' }]
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 10  }]
@Consumption.filter: { mandatory: true ,multipleSelections: true }
SalesOrder;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20,label: 'SalesOrderItem' }]
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 20  }]
SalesOrderItem;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30,label: 'Material' }]
Material;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40,label: 'MaterialName' }]
MaterialName;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50,label: 'OrderQuantity' }]
OrderQuantity ;
}

Step 4: Implement a Global Class – Develop a global class to retrieve data from the source view and convert it into XSTRING format for CSV output.

  METHOD get_sales_order.

    DATA : lt_data    TYPE z6na_tt_so_af,
           lv_xstring TYPE xstring.

    SELECT * FROM z6na_cds_bv_so_csv
      INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE _data
    WHERE salesorder = @i_vbeln.

    DATA(lv_csv) = |SalesOrder,SalesOrderItem,Material,MaterialName,OrderQuantity,OrderQuantityUnit{ cl_abap_char_utilities=>cr_lf }| &&
                    REDUCE string(
                    INIT lv_acc = ``
                    FOR <ls_out> IN lt_data
          NEXT lv_acc &&= |{ <ls_out>-salesorder },{ <ls_out>-salesorderitem },{ <ls_out>-material },{ <ls_out>-materialname },{ <ls_out>-orderquantity },{ <ls_out>-orderquantityunit }{ cl_abap_char_utilities=>cr_lf }|
 ).
    CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_STRING_TO_XSTRING'
      EXPORTING
        text     = lv_csv
        mimetype = 'text/csv'
*       ENCODING =
      IMPORTING
        buffer   = lv_xstring
      EXCEPTIONS
        failed   = 1
        OTHERS   = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
* Implement suitable error handling here
    ENDIF.

    r_form_content = lv_xstring.

  ENDMETHOD.

Step 5: Set Up an OData Project in SEGW – Create an OData project in SEGW to provide the download option for the CSV file.

Redefine the GET_STREAM method and write the logic there.

  method /IWBEP/IF_MGW_APPL_SRV_RUNTIME~GET_STREAM.

    DATA(lv_salesorder) = VALUE char10( it_key_tab[ name = 'salesdoc' ]-value OPTIONAL ).
    DATA(lv_csv_content) = new z6na_cl_so_csv( )->get_sales_order(
                                                 i_vbeln = conv #( lv_salesorder ) ).

    set_header( is_header = VALUE #( name = 'Content-Disposition'
                                     value = |attachment; filename={ lv_salesorder }.csv| ) ).

    copy_data_to_ref(
      EXPORTING
        is_data = VALUE /IWFND/IF_MGW_CORE_RUNTIME=>ty_s_media_resource(
        mime_type = 'text/csv'
        value     = lv_csv_content
    )
      CHANGING
        cr_data = er_stream
    ).
  endmethod.

Step 6 : Add Attachment Link Fields – Include the attachment/download link fields in the basic view, root view, and metadata extension.

Here, we need to attach the service name which we created in SEGW.

In Basic view,

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Basic View for SO - CSV File'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
@VDM.viewType: #BASIC
define view entity z6na_cds_bv_so_csv as select from I_SalesOrder
{
    key SalesOrder,
    key _Item.SalesOrderItem,
        _Item.Material,
        _Item._MaterialText.MaterialName,
        @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'OrderQuantityUnit'
        _Item.OrderQuantity,
        _Item.OrderQuantityUnit,
        'PreviewFile' as ShowCSV,
        cast(concat('/sap/opu/odata/SAP/Z6NA_ODATA_CSV_SRV/e_salesdocSet(''', concat( lpad(SalesOrder, 10, '0'), ''')/$value') ) 
        as abap.sstring(1300)) as LinkToCSV
}

In Root View , add the preview and link field.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Root View Entity for SO- CSV'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity z6na_cds_rv_so_csv as select from z6na_cds_bv_so_csv
{
    key SalesOrder,
    key SalesOrderItem,
         Material,
         MaterialName,
         @Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'OrderQuantityUnit'
         OrderQuantity,
         OrderQuantityUnit,
         ShowCSV,
         LinkToCSV
}

In metadata extension , add the URL(LinkToCSV field) in the UI annotation.

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
annotate entity z6na_cds_rv_so_csv
  with  
{
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10,label: 'SalesOrder' }]
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 10  }]
@Consumption.filter: { mandatory: true ,multipleSelections: true }
SalesOrder;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20,label: 'SalesOrderItem' }]
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 20  }]
SalesOrderItem;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30,label: 'Material' }]
Material;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40,label: 'MaterialName' }]
MaterialName;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50,label: 'OrderQuantity' }]
OrderQuantity ;
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 60,label: 'CSV' },{ type:#WITH_URL ,url: 'LinkToCSV' }]
ShowCSV;
}

Step 7: Expose the Service – Create a service definition and service binding to make the functionality available for consumption.

@EndUserText.label: 'Service Definition for SO - CSV'
define service Z6na_cds_sd_so_csv {
  expose z6na_cds_rv_so_csv;
}

Step 8: Preview the application.

Conclusion: 

By following these steps, we successfully enabled CSV file download in a RAP application using SEGW. This approach not only simplifies data export for end users but also demonstrates how RAP and SEGW can work together to deliver practical business functionality.

entry.title: CURP Validation in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Using Business Rules
entry.content:
Introduction: Enhancing Standard Format Checks with Logic-Based Validation

When working with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, ensuring the accuracy of national identifiers is critical — especially for country-specific IDs like the Mexican CURP (Clave Única de Registro de Población).

As you may know, Employee Central does offer a standard CURP validation, but it's restricted to format checking. It ensures the CURP is 18 characters and follows the right structure — but it does not validate the embedded logic, like date of birth, gender, or state code.

If you’ve struggled with CURP validation in SuccessFactors, or you're looking to make your system more robust and compliant, this solution is simple and scalable.

In this blog, I’ll share how I implemented a custom Business Rule to take CURP validation a step further — by checking that the value entered is not just syntactically correct, but also logically valid based on employee data.

Standard vs. Enhanced Validation

Validation Type       

 Format Check (Standard)

 Logic Check (Custom Rule)

 Length (18 chars)     

 ✅ Yes                  

 ✅ Yes                    

 Character pattern     

 ✅ Yes                  

 ✅ Yes                    

 Date of birth matching

 ❌ No                   

 ✅ Yes                    

 Gender validation     

 ❌ No                   

 ✅ Yes                    

 State code validation 

 ❌ No                   

 ✅ Yes                    

As shown above, the standard validation stops at format. With the Business Rule we extend that to cross-check the CURP content against the employee’s own data — a must-have for maintaining high-quality HR records.

Where This Rule Lives

The rule is configured in the National ID portlet of Employee Central and applies specifically when ID Type = CURP. It triggers during the Hire/Rehire onSave event to ensure validation before saving the record.

I’ll be sharing the exact configuration, regex pattern, and logical checks I used — including how we:

  • Parse CURP values to extract DOB, gender, and state code
  • Compare them with the employee’s actual personal data
  • Raise friendly error messages when something doesn’t match

Why Bother with Logic Checks?

Here’s why this matters:

  • Compliance: Inaccurate CURPs can lead to issues with government filings and audits.
  • Data Integrity: Avoid storing incorrect identifiers that may affect integrations or reporting.
  • User Experience: Prevent users from unknowingly entering wrong data that gets saved without warning.

Stay Tuned

In my next section below, I’ll walk you through:

  • The full business rule logic I used
  • The regex pattern for CURP format validation
  • How to match CURP-encoded DOB with the employee’s `dateOfBirth` field
  • State code validation using `Picklist` or constant arrays

This is a no-code, configuration-only solution that doesn’t require any external tools — just SAP standard functionality and a smart business rule.

Proposed Solution

Business Rule Variants

The logic in CURP involves checking consonants and vowels based on specific characters. To perform this validation, we need to create variants to find these values. Unfortunately, we have to create three different variants for all consonants, since the validations are performed in three different fields. The variants should be created as shown in the example below:

Sample from Demo

Business Rule Conditions

Moving on to the conditions that we must have the rule to perform all validations, below I will break down the explanation according to each part of the CURP logic, this way it will be easier to understand.

You'll notice that in the rule conditions below, I'm already considering "transforming" the name field letters into uppercase, since in ID they are always capitalized. This prevents the name fields from being all filled in with capital letters. If the customer requests the name fields in uppercase, I recommend removing this function from the rule.

 

  1. In the first condition, it is checked whether it is not CURP, the rule is already skipped, in this way we optimize and contribute to the performance of the System.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: First initial letter of the first surname.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: The first internal vowel of the first surname.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Initial letter of the second last name.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: The first letter of the first name.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Two digits of the year of birth.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Two digits of the month of birth.

Sample from Demo

 Validation: Two digits of the day of birth.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Gender - Males are assigned the letter H, Females are given the letter M, and others are assigned the letter N.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: Tow letters of the State of Birth.

Sample from Demo

For this validation I have added the two letters of each state of birth to the picklist label, to make it simple, and in the rule, we are reading that value inside of the parentheses. Example below of a picklist value.

Sample from Demo

Note: If you have defined the “State of Birth” as part of the Biographical Information CSF it will not be possible to retrieve this data, as the rule has a limitation today and does not allow us to access this table.

  1. Validation: The first internal consonant of the first surname.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: The first internal consonant of the second last name.

Sample from Demo

  1. Validation: The first internal consonant of the first name.

Sample from Demo

Additional Resources

As the rule has many validations and extensive variants, I am sharing the rule in a format to be imported but remember that the configuration you have may be a little different from my demo, so after importing you will have to make possible adjustments. Download HERE.

I'm also sharing HERE the link to the guide that explains all the rule functions in case you want to delve deeper into the ones used in the rule.

Conclusion

While SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central provides a good foundation for CURP validation through standard format checks, it's not enough to guarantee data accuracy and compliance in real-world scenarios. By implementing a custom Business Rule, we can go beyond the basics and ensure that CURP values not only follow the expected structure but also make logical sense based on the employee’s personal information.

This approach is entirely configuration-based, requires no custom development, and is easy to maintain — making it a smart enhancement for any organization operating in Mexico.

Validating CURP logic at the point of entry helps avoid downstream errors, ensures alignment with legal requirements, and maintains the integrity of your HR data.

I hope this solution helps you improve your Employee Central setup. Feel free to reach out or comment if you’d like to share how you’ve tackled CURP validation in your own environment.
